intro: Galopina crocyllioides, commonly known as the yellow globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its showy, yellow, globular flower heads that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a common sight in arid and semi-arid environments. Galopina crocyllioides is also known for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
